profiledesc.creation: Finding aid encoded in NoteTab Pro. Encoded by Jasmine Jones. 2015-07-28

did.head: Collection Overview
did.unittitle: Inez Whipple Wilder Papers
did.abstract: Contains news clippings, photographs, research and publications from Inez Whipple Wilder's professional papers.

bioghist.p: Inez Whipple Wilder was born in Diamond Hill, Rhode Island in 1871 to Eliab Daniel and Sarah (Wheaton) Whipple. She graduated from Rhode Island Normal School in 1890 and the in 1900 she received her Ph.B from Brown University. Wilder taught for several years at the Rhode Island State Normal School and at Northampton High School, until she joined the Smith College faculty in 1902. In 1904, Wilder received her A.M in biology. In 1906, Wilder married Professor Harris Hawthorne Wilder of the biology department who she worked alongside until his death in 1928, when she succeeded him as head of the department. While at Smith, Inez Wilder studied salamander morphology, as well as pioneering the study of finger prints. She died of a long illness in 1929.

scopecontent.p: The collection contains the professional papers of Inez Whipple Wilder. These include some biographical information, like photographs and obituaries, but the majority of the collection is taken up by Wilder's numerous publications and by her research.

accessrestrict.p: The records are open for research according to the regulations of the Smith College Archives without any additional restrictions.

userestrict.p: Single photocopies may be made for research purposes. Permission to publish material from the documents must be requested from the Smith College Archives. Smith College owns copyright to any published material relating to college events and activities. Provenance and copyright ownership of other materials is unknown and researchers are responsible for determining any question of copyright.

prefercite.p: Please use the following format when citing materials from this collection:
Inez Whipple Wilder Papers, Box #, Smith College Archives.

acqinfo.p: The Inez Whipple Wilder papers were donated to the College Archives.
